Weakness: Sensitive data exposure - Device ID/serial no
Description: An attacker could gather more critical information regarding to internals of the device which makes easy to conduct other various attacks.

Weakness: Firmware/storage extraction - Insecure external media interfaces
Description: An attacker could copy the firmware/storage and even modify firmware if device allows to physically remove the storage media (SD Card, USB).

Weakness: Firmware/storage extraction - Download from the Web
Description: An attacker could download the firmware from the manufacturer's website if access to the firmware image without authentication is possible.
An attacker could dump the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the serial bus protocol SPI.
An attacker could dump the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the serial bus protocol I2C.
An attacker could dump the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the serial interface UART.
An attacker could dump the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the debug interface JTAG.
An attacker could dump the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the debug interface SWD.
An attacker could dump the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the other SoC (System on Chip) (i.e. Bluetooth).

An attacker could dump the firmware by tapping if it is stored an embedded Multi Media Card (eMMC) flash chip (embedded SD card). An attacker could dump the firmware by unsoldering chip then reading it with an adapter if it is stored in an embedded Multi Media Card (eMMC) flash chip (embedded SD card).
An attacker could modify the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the serial interface UART.
An attacker could modify the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the debug interface JTAG.
An attacker could modify the firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the debug interface SWD.

Weakness: Grant shell access - Insecure UART interface
Description: An attacker could grant a command shell if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the serial interface UART.

Weakness: Grant shell access - Insecure SPI interface
Description: An attacker could grant a command shell if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the serial interface SPI.

Weakness: Change code execution flow - Insecure JTAG/SWD interface
Description: An attacker could debug the libraries/binaries and manipulate the execution flow of firmware if access to the flash/EEPROM chip is not restricted through the debug interface JTAG.
An attacker could misuse reset functionality of the device if resetting results in insecure state.
An attacker could reveal unchangable credentials including password, hash, private certificate, and API key from storage by reverse engineering and source code analysis.
An attacker could discover (undocumented) backdoor account from non-volatile data by reverse engineering and source code analysis.

Weakness: Sensitive data exposure - Encryption keys and algorithms
Description: An attacker could identify encryption keys from both storage and memory by reverse engineering and source code analysis. An attacker could gain sensitive data if device has encrypted with the discovered keys.

Weakness: Sensitive data exposure - Other sensitive information
Description: An attacker could identify various sensitive data (i.e. URLs) from both storage and memory by reverse engineering and source code analysis. An attacker could gain sensitive data if device lacks of disk encryption.

Weakness: Sensitive data exposure - Static and same encryption keys
Description: An attacker could gain sensitive data of other devices if firmware uses static and same encryption keys.

Weakness: Configuration - Lack of data integrity checks
Description: An attacker could backdoor the firmware if firmware has insecure or lack of integrity checks.
Lack of deprovisioning/decomissioning. Inability to wipe device's local data storage â€¦ <This should be triggered via device web page>

Weakness: Configuration - Insecure customization of OS platforms
Description: Insecure default settings or insufficient ability to harden the system by modifying configurations are the root cause of many vulnerabilities.
Insecure default settings or insufficient ability to harden the system by modifying configurations are the root cause of many vulnerabilities.
Insecure default settings or insufficient ability to harden the system by modifying configurations are the root cause of many vulnerabilities.
Disclosure or reusing of Sensitive data (session key, token, cookie, etc.) could cause authentication bypass.

Weakness: Authentication bypass - Device to mobile application
Description: Disclosure or reusing of Sensitive data (session key, token, cookie, etc.) could cause authentication bypass.
Disclosure or reusing of Sensitive data (session key, token, cookie, etc.) could cause authentication bypass.
Devices will eventually remain vulnerable as the device does not have the ability to update.

Weakness: Update mechanism - Lack of manual update
Description: Devices will remain vulnerable until an automatic update is triggered, during which time an attacker could compromise the device. (No ability to manually force an update check for the device)

Weakness: Update mechanism - Lack of transport encryption
Description: An attacker could capture firmware via a transparent proxy if network traffic is unencrypted. (Updates are transmitted over the network without using TLS or encrypting the update file itself)

Weakness: Update mechanism - Lack of signature on update file
Description: An attacker could backdoor the firmware if firmware update file has insecure or lack of digital signature.

Weakness: Update mechanism - Lack of update verification
Description: An attacker could backdoor the firmware if firmware update process has insecure or lack of integrity verification.

Weakness: Update mechanism - Lack of update authentication
Description: An attacker could download the firmware if firmware update process has insecure or lack of authentication.
An attacker could capture firmware even from encrypted traffic if update mechanism is not secure against MitM attacks.
(Malicious firmware update). An attacker could backdoor the firmware/sensitive data 'on the fly' before reaching the device/hub if update mechanism is not secure against MitM attacks.

Weakness: Update mechanism - World writable update location
Description: An attacker could modify firmware if storage location for update files is world writable.

Weakness: Update mechanism - Lack of anti-rollback mechanism
Description: An attacker could revert firmware back (firmware downgrade) to a vulnerable version if the device lacks of anti-rollback mechanism.
Any kind of senstive data that can be accessible.
Insecure network communication. Network services are not properly encrypted HTTPS to prevent eavesdropping or tampering senstive data by attackers.

Encryption is implemented however it is improperly configured or is not being properly updated, (e.g. expired and/or self-signed certificates, same certificate used on multiple devices, deprecated SSL versions)
Ability to collect a set of valid usernames by interacting with the authentication mechanism

Ability to set account passwords to '1234' or '123456' for example. Usage of pre-programmed (known) default passwords (deffpass.com (Publicly available) - IoT device default password lookup). Easily guessable credentials. Brute-force by dictionaries and rules
Ability to continue sending authentication attempts after 3 - 5 failed login attempts
Insecure password reset/forgot mechanism could cause authentication bypass.
For example: Exposed services running as root

Weakness: Implicitly trusted by device or cloud

Description: Insecure network communication. Mobile applications are not properly encrypted HTTPS to prevent eavesdropping or tampering senstive data by attackers.

Encryption is implemented however it is improperly configured or is not being properly updated, (e.g. expired and/or self-signed certificates, same certificate used on multiple devices, deprecated SSL versions)
Known vulnerabilities in deprecated libraries.
Insecure Device controlling commands
No check whether the device is working as it should. Insecure heartbeats
Insecure network communication. Attacker can extract sensitive information in clear text from radio packets.

Interception and modification. Attacker can intercept live radio communication and then modify the transmitted packets. Even TLS connections might be also vulnerable to MitM attacks, since certificate validation is missing. It allows the attackers to conduct additional attacks according to the context [EST-1].

The transmission protocol does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the transmitted data, such as a checksum. Or it does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or checksums of a message (header or payload) which will allow modified or corrupted data in transmission.

Attacker can perform bit-flip attacks on encrypted network traffic. The intruder will first intercept an encrypted message and then alter the payload or header and retransmit the data packet. Actually performing replay attack which is possible when there is no verification and captured data can be re-transmitted. Some type of integrity check methods i.e. ICV are known as vulnerable.

Due to some controls such as payload verification, a transmitted packet might not be re-transmitted again. For this cases, it is required jamming the signal first and capturing an "unused" radio packet. Then replay attack can be successfully performed.
Attacker can present itself as a legitamate gateway or sensor in radio communication.
Attacker can disrupt radio communication.
